'''''Ramaria stricta''''', [[common name|commonly]] known as the '''strict-branch coral''' is a [[coral fungus]] of the genus ''[[Ramaria]]''. It has a [[cosmopolitan distribution]], and grows on dead wood, stumps, trunks, and branches of both [[deciduous]] and [[coniferous tree]]s. Its [[basidiocarp|fruit body]] is up to {{convert|10|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} tall, made of multiple slender, compact, and vertical parallel branches. Its color is typically light [[tan (color)|tan]] to [[wine (color)|vinaceous]]-brown. All parts of the mushroom will bruise when handled. There are several lookalike corals that can usually be distinguished from ''R. stricta'' by differences in coloration, bruising reaction, or microscopic features. The fungus is inedible due to its unpleasant odor and bitter taste.

==Taxonomy==

The species was originally [[species description|described]] under the name ''Clavaria stricta'' by [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]] in 1795.<ref name="Persoon 1795"/> In 1888, French mycologist [[Lucien Quélet]] transferred the species to the genus ''[[Ramaria]]''.<ref name="Quelet 1888"/>

It is commonly known as the "upright coral".<ref name="Roberts 2011"/>

==Description==

The color of the fruit body is light yellow brown to paler toward extremities, the tips are light yellow; bruising light reddish brown. The basidiocarp has a leathery texture when fresh, but becomes brittle when dry. The stipe is branched up to 8 times, and the branches are all  upright and nearly parallel. The branches ending in 4 to 5 thornlike tips.<ref name="Schalkwijk-Barendsen1991"/> Overall, the fruit body appears bushy, and is medium-sized, up to {{convert|10|by|7|cm|in|abbr=on}}. The stipe is single or branching from the base; with white [[mycelium]] and [[rhizomorph]]s radiating from the base. The odor is of anise. The taste is bitter.<ref name="Tylutki 1987II"/> The fruit bodies are "edible but unpalatable."<ref name="Orr 1979"/>

The [[spore print]] is dark yellow. [[Spore]]s are roughly elliptical, dotted with low [[cyanophilous]] warts, and measure 7–10 by 3.5–5.5 [[micrometre|μm]]. The [[basidia]] have basal clamps are mostly four-spored, and sometimes have cyanophilous granular contents.<ref name="Tylutki 1987II"/>

===Variants===

Several variants have been described:

: var. ''alba''
: var. ''concolor''
: var. ''fumida''
: var. ''violaceo-tincta''

===Similar species===

Another widespread and common coral, ''[[Ramaria apiculata|R. apiculata]]'', typically grows on conifer wood, and bruises brown like ''R. stricta'', but it has green pigmentation.<ref name="Orr 1979"/> ''R. apiculata'' is a dull buff-tan to dull orange-brown, and young fruit bodies  often have white branch tips.<ref name="Arora 1986"/> ''[[Ramaria gracilis|R. gracilis]]'' prefers conifer wood, and has lighter colors than ''R. stricta''. The tropical ''[[Ramara moelleriana|R. moelleriana]]'' can only be reliably distinguished from ''R. sticta'' by location and microscopic characteristics.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> ''[[Ramaria flava|R. flava]]'' is [[mycorrhiza]]l, and grows under coniferous and deciduous trees. Its fruit bodies are typically taller, have a more  unpleasant odor, and a less bitter taste.<ref name="Kibby 1994"/>

==Distribution and habitat==

''Ramaria stricta'' has a [[cosmopolitan distribution]],<ref name="Schalkwijk-Barendsen1991"/> and is a fairly common species. The fungus is [[lignicolous]], common in late summer and fall in [[coniferous forest]]s of the [[Pacific Coast]] and [[Rocky Mountain]]s.<ref name="Orr 1979"/> The fungus grows on dead wood, stumps, trunks, and branches of both [[deciduous|leafy]] and [[coniferous tree]]s.<ref name="Corner 1950"/> The form that grows on deciduous wood tends to be more orange and less bushy than those which grow on coniferous wood. Fruit bodies can form in "log lines" where decaying wood is buried underground near the surface, or is in an advanced state of decomposition.<ref name="Arora 1986"/>
